oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Bovine Vaccines: Which work best and what's new or coming?
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Schultz, Kevin T.
Israel, Barbara A.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: vaccine
attenuated microorganism
killed microorganism
effectiveness
suitability
immune system
infectious process
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A vaccine can be defined as an attenuated microorganism, a killed microorganism, or a part or product of a microorganism which is administered to an animal for the prevention, amelioration or treatment of an infectious disease. There are a wide variety of vaccines available to the bovine practitioner for use in cattle, and therefore selecting the most appropriate vaccines for a particular situation can be difficult. The effectiveness and suitability of a vaccine depends upon the nature of the immune response it generates and on the role that the immune system may play in preventing or regulating the infectious process of a particualr microorganism.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: American Association of Bovine Practitioners Conference Proceedings; 1990; 20-22
